datasets.name: Hibiscus Leaf Disease Dataset
datasets.description: High-quality Hibiscus leaf images collected under natural conditions in Bangladesh to support research on leaf disease classification and plant health monitoring.

classes.name: Healthy
classes.description: Leaves without visible damage or disease.
classes.cure: No treatment needed. Maintain regular watering and monitor for early signs of disease.

classes.name: Mild Edge Damage
classes.description: Edges slightly discolored or dried, possibly due to minor nutrient deficiency or physical stress.
classes.cure: Trim damaged areas and apply a balanced NPK fertilizer; ensure adequate watering.

classes.name: Citruspot
classes.description: Circular or irregular yellow-orange spots on leaf surface.
classes.cure: Spray with copper-based fungicide (e.g., copper oxychloride) and remove infected leaves.

classes.name: Slightly Diseased
classes.description: Early visible signs of leaf infection or fungal growth.
classes.cure: Apply neem oil spray twice weekly; isolate affected plants if necessary.

classes.name: Early Mild Spotting
classes.description: Tiny, scattered dark spots at early infection stage.
classes.cure: Use Mancozeb 75% WP fungicide and avoid overhead watering.

classes.name: Wrinkled
classes.description: Distorted or wrinkled leaf surfaces often due to viral infection or pest stress.
classes.cure: Apply insecticidal soap for pests and remove heavily infected leaves.

classes.name: Senescent
classes.description: Naturally aging or yellowing leaves.
classes.cure: No cure needed. Remove senescent leaves to improve air circulation.

classes.name: Fungal Infected
classes.description: Dark patches or mold growth caused by fungal pathogens.
classes.cure: Use systemic fungicide such as Carbendazim and ensure good drainage.

datasets.name: Tea Leaf Disease Dataset
datasets.description: Tea leaf dataset collected under natural lighting for disease detection and crop health analysis.

classes.name: Algal Leaf Spot
classes.description: Gray-green to reddish-brown circular patches caused by algae.
classes.cure: Apply copper fungicides and improve field drainage.

classes.name: Brown Blight
classes.description: Irregular brown lesions leading to leaf drop.
classes.cure: Spray with Captan or Chlorothalonil; prune infected branches.

classes.name: Grey Blight
classes.description: Grayish patches with dark margins caused by Pestalotiopsis species.
classes.cure: Apply copper oxychloride or Mancozeb; ensure proper plant spacing.

classes.name: Healthy
classes.description: Leaves without disease symptoms.
classes.cure: Maintain balanced fertilizer and regular pest inspection.

classes.name: Red Leaf Spot
classes.description: Circular reddish lesions often surrounded by yellow halos.
classes.cure: Apply Bordeaux mixture (1%) and remove infected leaves.

datasets.name: Bottle Gourd Leaf Disease Dataset
datasets.description: Dataset containing diverse leaf images of bottle gourd plants affected by common diseases, captured in natural farm environments.

classes.name: Anthracnose
classes.description: Sunken dark spots on leaves caused by Colletotrichum fungus.
classes.cure: Use copper-based fungicides and remove infected debris.

classes.name: Mosaic Virus
classes.description: Mosaic-like green-yellow pattern on leaves due to viral infection.
classes.cure: Remove infected plants; control aphids and whiteflies; use virus-free seeds.

classes.name: Alternaria Leaf Blight
classes.description: Brown concentric spots that enlarge under humid conditions.
classes.cure: Apply Mancozeb or Chlorothalonil at 10-day intervals.

classes.name: Healthy
classes.description: Leaves showing no visible disease or pest damage.
classes.cure: Continue regular pest monitoring and maintain proper field hygiene.

classes.name: Downy Mildew
classes.description: Yellow spots on upper surface with white fungal growth underneath.
classes.cure: Use Metalaxyl or Mancozeb fungicide and improve air circulation.

classes.name: Early Alternaria Leaf Blight
classes.description: Initial small brown spots with yellow borders.
classes.cure: Spray with a fungicide like Dithane M-45 and remove infected leaves.

classes.name: Fungal Damage Leaf
classes.description: Irregular dark patches caused by fungal infection.
classes.cure: Apply Carbendazim and ensure proper soil drainage.

classes.name: Angular Leaf Spot
classes.description: Water-soaked angular lesions on leaf veins caused by bacteria.
classes.cure: Use copper hydroxide sprays and avoid overhead irrigation.

datasets.name: Papaya Leaf Disease Dataset
datasets.description: Real-world dataset of papaya leaves in both healthy and diseased conditions, captured under natural outdoor environments to assist in disease classification.

classes.name: Bacterial Blight
classes.description: Leaf spots caused by bacterial infections.
classes.cure: Use copper-based bactericides and remove infected leaves.

classes.name: Carica Insect Hole
classes.description: Insect damage resulting in holes on the leaf surface.
classes.cure: Apply insecticidal soap and control insect population.

classes.name: Curled Yellow Spot
classes.description: Yellow spots with curled edges, indicative of pest or fungal damage.
classes.cure: Use neem oil or fungicide and remove damaged leaves.

classes.name: Healthy Leaf
classes.description: Leaves without any visible disease symptoms.
classes.cure: Regular watering and pest control.

classes.name: Pathogen Symptoms
classes.description: Various symptoms including spots, wilting, and discoloration.
classes.cure: Use appropriate fungicide or pesticide based on pathogen type.

classes.name: Yellow Necrotic Spots Holes
classes.description: Yellow spots that later develop into necrosis, often from viral infections.
classes.cure: Remove affected leaves and apply appropriate fungicide.
